comment._content:
From the account of the trial in Freeman's August 16th 1842
Her appearance in court produced a great sensation, and the utmost curiosity was evinced to catch a glimpse of her face or person. She was attired in the deepest weeds, made according to the most modern fashion, and wore a double veil of dense crepe, which, even when lifted, fell around her face in such thick drapery as to render her face almost invisible. In her hand she held a rich bouquet, and her demeanour throughout the whole proceedings was characterised by the most unruffled composure, and the utmost self-possession.
The trial certainly excited a great deal of public interest. Freeman's Journal devoted well over a page to coverage of each of the 2 days of the trial. The coverage began with this paragraph (Freeman's Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser, Tuesday, August 16, 1842):
Yesterday being the day fixed for the trial of Ellen Byrne, for the alleged murder of her husband, the utmost excitement was manifested in the public mind throughout every district of the city, and more particularly in the vicinity of Green-street, which, with all the adjoining avenues, comprising the whole line of streets lying in the direction of Capel-street, Great Britain-street, Henry-street, Essex-bridge, &c. &c., was crowded at an early hour of the morning to such an excess as to be rendered almost wholly impassable. Indeed the crowds of the idle and the curious who congregated in this portion of the city were so dense as to be wholly incalculable, and it is not a little surprising that no accident or fatality of any description whatsoever should have occurred amid so vast a multitude, naturally excited by a proceeding of deep popular interest, and who, one and all, evidenced the deepest anxiety as to every circumstance connected with the melancholy and mysterious occurrence which furnished the occasion for yesterday's investigation.
and ended, after what looks like a verbatim account of the cross-examinations with this (Freeman's Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser, Wednesday, August 17, 1842):
The jury retired at twenty minutes to four, and having been absent from court about half an hour, returned with a verdict of NOT GUILTY. The announcement of this finding was received with murmurs in the court-house. Clerk of the Crown. - Discharge the prisoner. The ponderous bolt of the dock was shot back, and the prisoner was free as the freest of the eager spectators who had assembled to witness her trial. The court adjourned till the 26th of October. The crowds which congregated in front of Newgate were enormous, and the most marked dissatisfaction was manifested by the populace at the result of the trial. Mrs. Byrne remained for an hour and a half in the court-house, after the rising of the court, in the hope that the patience of the crowds assembled without would be exhausted at length, and that when they saw that the object of their curiosity did not appear, that they would quietly separate. In this expectation, however, she was mistaken; the mob was not to be baffled, and were it not for a ruse of the police she might have remained in the court-house till midnight. At seven o'clock, however. Mr Inspector Wade ordered a covered car to be drawn up at the entrance to Newgate, and he conducted into the vehicle a female resembling the prisoner in stature, but who was dressed in such deep weeds that her face was rendered wholly invisible. The pseudo Mrs. Byrne entered the car with the inspector, and away rolled the jarvey, escorted by a number of the horse police, amid the hooting and angry exclamations of the infuriate populace. As soon as the car arrived at the corner of Harcourt-street the widow got out and walked quietly about her business. Mr Wade returned to Green-street, which was as desolate as if there had never been 5 people together there since the world began. Another car as then procured. Mrs Byrne, "the true and genuine," drove away in the company of her sons amid the utmost tranquillity.

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] You might think they didn't hang about, but in his summing up Mr Pennefather said that the inquiry (i.e. inquest) had taken place "for a lengthened period, almost unexampled in its duration." The inquest had received a great deal of publicity, and the judge warned the jury to ignore anything they had read about it.

Further browsing shows that the inquest (largely because of adjournments) lasted 20 days, and didn't reach a conclusion until August 4th. On the 5th Freeman's said that it had "dragged its weary length to a conclusion."

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] At that time, in the case of a guilty verdict, murderers were usually executed 2 or 3 weeks later (although of course Mrs Byrne left the court without a stain on her character - just a very nasty stain on her bedlinen).

For instance, John Delahunt was convicted of murder on January 15th 1842 and executed at Kilmainham on February 5th (in front of a crowd of "not less than 10,000 persons" although if you weren't there, you could read a <u>very</u> detailed account of his last moments in Freeman's Journal).

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It's behind a paywall unfortunately, but if you can just hold one minute... From Thursday, 24 July 1873 in the Irish Times, page 3:
DEATH OF MR. JONATHAN HENN, Q.C. The public will regret to learn that one of the most distinguished advocates in the celebrated State trial of Daniel O'Connell and his co-traversers, in the Repeal prosecutions in 1843, died on Tuesday. Mr Jonathan Henn, the gentleman referred to, had long retired from practice, but his reputation as one of the most brilliant orators of a brilliant period, associated as he was with Richard Lalor Shiel, James Whiteside, Thomas O'Hagan, Gerald Fitzgibbon, sen, and Francis Macdonogh, still lives fresh in the memory of the Bar and the people of this country. Those who have read the reports of the memorable trials in question, although unacquainted with his imposing figure and persuasive delivery, will not have failed to have pourtrayed [sic] to themselves a character singularly great even among those who are now recognised as his great compeers. Amongst his contemporaries he was always regarded as an ornament to his profession. He was called to the Bar in the year 1811, after a distinguished collegiate career, and in the year 1835 "took silk" as a Queen's Counsel. Soon after his great display in the O'Connell case, Mr Henn declined practice, and for the last 20 years he has never appeared in a court of justice as an advocate. Mr Henn died at Clifton Villa, Bray, at the advanced age of 84 years.
